awd_titl_txt: Optical Micromachined Ultrasound Transducers (OMUT) for High Resolution 3D Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to develop Optical Micromachined Ultrasound Transducer (OMUT) technology for high-resolution imaging probes mountable on a tip of a needle or small diameter tubing. The design relies on laser generated ultrasound and optical detection of ultrasound. Therefore all signal communication to and from the device is optical. Ultrasound is generated by rapid absorption of short laser pulses in a thin film. Optical micro-cavity resonators having a flexible top membrane form high sensitivity ultrasound detectors.

The two key features of OMUTs, miniaturization and all-optical connectivity, make it an ideal technology for medical applications such as real-time guiding of cardiovascular interventions, laparoscopic surgery, and deep brain electrode implantation. Another added value of this technology is the facilitation of pulse/echo ultrasound imaging and photoacoustic imaging (PAI) in a single device. Combining ultrasound imaging and PAI provides a range of possibilities for the design of multi-modality, functional, and molecular imaging systems for higher specificity in medical diagnosis and therapy guidance.

por.por_cntn:
During the first year of the project we have designed and fabricated ultrasound detectors based on optical sensing. The device design is based on a thin polymer membrane that deforms under applicationof acoustic pressure. The membrane is coated by a high reflectivity metalic mirror coating that forms an optical resonator and facilitates optical sensing of ultrasound. The optical resonance wavelength changes in response to theexternal acoustic pressure. We have developed fabrication processes emplying microfabrication technology. We have used this fabrication process to fabricate different devices having a range of parmaeters spanning different device sizes and differentthicknesses of membrane. These devices have been tested and characterized for their acoustic sensitivityand receiving bandwidth. Test results have demonstarated the high sensitivity of these devices. However, the bandwidth of these devices has been relativelynarrow. The narrow bandwidth is a result of a series of internal acoustic reflections between the top andbottom interfaces of the membrane and lateral acoustic oscillations. These effects preclude the use of thistype of device in imaging applications due to the low bandwidth.

A new approach to the design of the devices have been adopted during the second year of the project. In this approach the optical confinement is achieved by inducing a lateral modification of the refractive index within the polymer layer and creating a vertical waveguide. This allows to eliminate the polymer-air interface and thus improve the acoustic bandwidth of the device. Several devices have been fabricated using the modified design. The devices were tested using a calibrated acoustic hydrophone. The test results showed a remarkable improvement in both sensitivity and bandwidth in comparison to the previous design. The sensitivity increased by a factor of 40. The bandwidth is wide to allow the application og these devices in high resolution imaging applications.
